Title: Information Exposure Through An Error Message
Details: Information Exposure Through An Error Message The sensitive information may be valuable information on its own (such as a password), or it may be useful for launching other, more deadly attacks. For more information checkout the CWE-209 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/209.html) advisory.

Title: Public Class Not Declared as Final
Details: The class is not declared as final as per OWASP recommendations. It is considered best practice to make classes final where possible and practical (i.e. It has no classes which inherit from it). Non-Final classes can allow an attacker to extend a class in a malicious manner. Manually inspect the code to determine whether or not it is practical to make this class final.

Title: Class Contains Public Variable: body
Details: The class variable may be accessed and modified by other classes without the use of getter/setter methods. It is considered unsafe to have public fields or methods in a class unless required as any method, field, or class that is not private is a potential avenue of attack. It is safer to provide accessor methods to variables in order to limit their accessibility.

Title: Cross-site Scripting (XSS)
Details: Unsanitized input from an HTTP parameter flows into here, where it is used to render an HTML page returned to the user. This may result in a Cross-Site Scripting attack (XSS).

Title: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
Details: Unsanitized input from an HTTP parameter flows into org.jsoup.Jsoup.connect, where it is used as an URL to perform a request. This may result in a Server-Side Request Forgery vulnerability.

Title: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
Details: Unsanitized input from an HTTP parameter flows into org.jsoup.Jsoup.connect, where it is used as an URL to perform a request. This may result in a Server-Side Request Forgery vulnerability.

Title: Command Injection
Details: Unsanitized input from an HTTP parameter flows into command, where it is used as a shell command. This may result in a Command Injection vulnerability.

Title: SQL Injection
Details: Unsanitized input from an HTTP parameter flows into executeQuery, where it is used in an SQL query. This may result in an SQL Injection vulnerability.
